definitions.definition: a very strong feeling of love, hate, anger, enthusiasm, etc.

examples.text: I admire the passion and commitment shown by the players.
She argued her case with considerable passion.
a **crime of passion** *(= caused by strong feelings of sexual )*
**Passions were running high** *(= people were angry and emotional)* at the meeting.
He's a man of violent passions.
That passion drove me to get to the top.
The team has been playing with renewed passion this season.
There were moments of high passion in the game.
This issue always arouses passion.
a speech full of passion

definitions.definition: a very strong feeling of liking something; a hobby, an activity, etc. that you like very much
definitions.sensetop: passion for somethingpassion for doing something

examples.text: Music is his true passion.
She left her job to **pursue her** lifelong **passion** for painting.
He was a quiet man with a passion for writing poetry.
They **shared a passion** for Italian food.
Music is a passion with him.
The English have a passion for gardens.
Elliot and Nina discovered a shared passion for poetry.
He developed a real passion for acting.
She had very little time to indulge her passion for painting.
his lifelong passion for aeroplanes
his renewed passion for the game

definitions.definition: a very strong feeling of sexual love

examples.text: His passion for her made him blind to everything else.
No one had ever aroused his passion as much as Sandra.
She didn't believe in grand passion or love at first sight.
He was her first great passion.
The passion between them had cooled.
They kissed with passion.
They spent a night of passion in a hotel.
Who is the object of his passion this time?

definitions.definition: a state of being very angry

examples.text: She **flies into a passion** if anyone even mentions his name.

definitions.definition: the suffering and death of Jesus Christ
if you love, hate, etc. somebody/something with a passion, you love, hate, etc. them/it very much

examples.text: To do this job you have to love architecture with a passion.
She hated him with a passion.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin passio(n-) (chiefly a term in Christian theology), from Latin pati ‘suffer’.
